text:
Good morning Lasma.

I’m back from holidays in time for the last week of work before Christmas! 

Yeah my Slack app has done the same thing for notifications... although we use it at my current studio for communication so I do have to check it regularly anyway.

Great to hear a bit more about your journey so far. It’s always good to follow where you feel that passion and enjoyment. Things change as well. Whether that is your desire to do something new or simply learning a new piece of software, it’s always good to stay flexible.

There always seems to be something new to learn :laughing:

For me, I’ve been a super Lord of the Rings fan most of my life and grew up watching the films. Seeing anything fantasy like that always got me drawing or creating. Then after working in a couple of other industries I visited an expo by Weta Workshop showcasing their concept art, DMP and practical effects.  It was then that I realised I wanted to properly venture into the world of VFX.

I have definitely found that I tend to prefer shots that focus on set extension, environment work and landscapes. There is something magical about creating a new world. :+1::skin-tone-2:

If your tutor has advised you to keep the graduate reel in there, then do that. The only reason I said that is so that things are nice and clear on the screen. Most showreels that contain breakdowns will be graduate reels anyway because studios usually only provide artists with a final shot.
What are you planning on doing to tailor your showreel more towards DMP?
Sometimes it’s helpful to see if your tutor would be able to place you any voluntary work on projects. You would be working on an actual project and would be able to use the shots in your showreel.
